metadata.case_name: Albert Moses & K. L. Dhawan v. State

facts.text: Appellants convicted under ss. 120B and 420 Indian Penal Code, and s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and sentenced to aggregate of six months rigorous imprisonment.
Appellant Albert Moses was the Principal in charge of the Rehabilitation Centre, Malviya Nagar and Kalkaji under the Ministry of Rehabilitation.
Appellant K. L. Dhawan was a partner in the firm M/s. Dhawan Co. and they supplied a surface plate for Rs. 1,950/- to the Works Centre of which appellant Albert Moses was the Principal.
Trial of appellants and R. P. Dhawan (acquitted) commenced before Mr. Jawala Das, Special Judge, Delhi on May 21, 1956; prosecution evidence closed on October 26, 1956.
Mr. P. D. Sharma, Special Judge, Delhi took up the case from December 20, 1956, examined defence witnesses, convicted appellants and acquitted R. P. Dhawan.
Appeal against conviction and sentence to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeals Nos. 3-D and 1-T of 1958; conviction and sentences upheld by judgment dated May 1958.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court against High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the proceedings are incompetent because the trial commenced before one Special Judge and was continued by another Special Judge after December 20, 1956, as s. 350 CrPC is not applicable.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mr. P. D. Sharma was not competent to proceed with the trial from the stage left by Mr. Jawala Das as s. 350 CrPC is not applicable when one Special Judge is succeeded by another.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 350 CrPC; Payara Lal v. State of Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions of Code of Criminal Procedure applicable insofar as not inconsistent with Criminal Law Amendment Act; Special Judge deemed to be a Court of Session.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 46 of 1952

court_reasoning.text: Question considered in Payara Lal v. State of Punjab where held that s. 8(3) of Act 46 of 1952 does not contemplate s. 350 CrPC becoming applicable to proceedings before Special Judge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 8(3) does not make s. 350 CrPC applicable to Special Judges

court_reasoning.text: Amendment made in Criminal Law Amendment Act by Act 2 of 1956 by which s. 3A was added making the provisions of s. 350 CrPC applicable.

holdings.text: Proceedings before Special Judge competent despite succession of judges in light of amendment adding s. 3A to Criminal Law Amendment Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Payara Lal v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s. 350 CrPC not applicable to succession of Special Judges under s. 8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act pre-amendment; question of amendment applicability noted

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Makes CrPC provisions applicable unless inconsistent; Special Judge deemed Court of Session

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Provision on succession of presiding officers; applicability to Special Judges disputed

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment (Amendment) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Added to make provisions of s. 350 CrPC applicable to proceedings before Special Judge

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected the sole ground challenging competence of second Special Judge to continue trial, upholding High Court judgment confirming conviction and sentence.

key_quotes.text: The sole question which has been raised in this Court is that... the proceedings are not competent and, therefore, the conviction and the sentence cannot be upheld.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Identifies the only issue in appeal

key_quotes.text: Counsel relies upon a judgment of this Court in Payara Lal v. State of Punjab in which it was held that s. 350 is not applicable when one Special Judge is succeeded by another.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summarises petitioner argument and key precedent
